description:
Aspergillus flavus NRRL3357 is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is a common environmental mold found in soil, decaying vegetation, and various agricultural commodities.

Aspergillus flavus NRRL3357 is characterized by its ability to produce a toxic secondary metabolite called aflatoxin, which is a potent carcinogen. This strain, NRRL3357, is a well-studied and widely used model organism for the investigation of aflatoxin biosynthesis and regulation.

The fungus exhibits a characteristic yellow-green to olive-green colony appearance on culture media, with a velvety or granular texture. Microscopically, it produces conidiophores (asexual spore-bearing structures) with globose vesicles and uniseriate phialides (specialized conidial cells) that give rise to the characteristic conidia (asexual spores).

Aspergillus flavus NRRL3357 has been extensively used in research to understand the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying aflatoxin production, as well as its potential role in human and animal health, and agricultural contamination. The availability of its genome sequence has further expanded the research opportunities for this important fungal species.
